title: Sunrise 'to scrap' popular Kochie's Angels opinion segment
title_page: Sunrise 'to scrap' popular Kochie's Angels opinion segment | Daily Mail Online
text:
They announced the sudden departure of weather reporter Edwina Bartholomew last week as part of the show's 2016 revamp.
Now Channel Seven's Sunrise will scrap the popular opinion segment, Kochie's Angels.
The Daily Telegraph reported on Friday that the network will replace the talk-back panel as of February.
Scroll down for video
Moving on: Channel Seven's Sunrise will scrap the popular opinion segment , Kochie's Angels next month as part of the show's revamp
Kochie's Angles will be replaced with a refreshed opinion segment, but it is not known if it will still be managed by the show's host David 'Kochie' Koch.
According to the publication the program's executive producer Michael Pell, notified panel regulars via email earlier in the week.
'I have made the decision to rest Kochie's Angles as a segment,' the email allegedly read.
Fresh approach: Kochie's Angles will be replaced with a refreshed opinion segment, but it is not known if it will still be managed by the show's host David 'Kochie' Koch (pictured)
Female: The panel is normally orientated with three leading females who talk all topical news
Talk back: Late last year Deborah Clay (L), Gretel Killeen (M) and Kyly Clarke (R) appeared on the panel
'I'd like to take the opportunity to thank you for your contribution and loyalty.'
The email concluded: 'Thank you for the insights and the laughs...I will miss our Kochie's Angel's lunches.'
Regular guests on the panel include Channel Seven correspondent and model Rachael Finch, presenter Kyly Clarke, Marie Claire publisher Jackie Frank, media personality MacSween and Sunrise news reporter Natalie Barr.
Daily Mail Australia has contacted Channel Seven for comment.
Appearances: Channel Seven correspondent and model Rachael Finch has also featured on the desk many of times in the past
Let go: The program's executive producer Michael Pell, allegedly notified panel regulars via email earlier in the week (pictured publisher Jackie Frank (L) and Olympia Elka Whalan (L) who are regulars on the show)
Dropping off: The news of the cancellations comes just days after weather reporter Edwina Bartholomew announced her departure from the role due to the revamp
The changes have been put into place after former Today Tonight executive producer Craig McPherson took over the reins for Channel Seven's news and public affairs last year.
And furthermore, the physical layout of the show's studio is set for a revamp too.
'Brekky Central' at Sydney's Martin Place studios is set to be transformed, with the new set designed by Jim Fenhagen.
Last week it was announced that Channel Nine was making some changes to its morning programs in a bid to compete against Sunrise.
Reasoning: The changes have been put into place after former Today Tonight executive producer Craig McPherson took over the reins for Channel Seven's news and public affairs last year
The Mornings show will be re-branded and launched as Today Extra when it returns on Monday February 8.
Sonia Kruger and David Campbell are set to return as co-hosts for the program in its normal time slot of 9 to 11.30am, following on from breakfast show Today and Weekend Today on Saturdays and Sundays.
Each show will also unveil a fresh look with refurbished sets, giving viewers a warm welcome into 2016, while Today Extra will endeavour to keep the focus on light entertainment news.
